question: Question 1 Which one of the following functions is analytic over the entire complex plane?
solution: [latex]f(z) = \cos z [/latex] is analytic every where.

question: Question 2 The families of curves represented by the solution of the equation [latex]\frac{dy}{dx}=-\left (\frac{x}{y} \right )^n[/latex] for [latex]n = -1[/latex] and [latex]n = +1[/latex], respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{d y}{d x} &=-\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)^{n} \\ n=-1\quad\quad \frac{d y}{d x} &=-\frac{y^{\prime}}{x} \\ \frac{d y}{y} &=-\frac{d x}{x} \\ \int \frac{1}{y} d y &=-\int \frac{1}{x} d x \\ \ln y &=-\ln x+\ln c \\ \ln (y x) &=\ln c \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] x y=c \quad [/latex] (Represents rectangular hyporbola) [latex] \begin{aligned} n=1, \quad \frac{d y}{d x}&=-\frac{x}{y} \\ y d y &=-x d x \\ y d y &=-\int x d x \\ \frac{y^{2}}{2} &=-\frac{x^{2}}{2}+c \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex] x^{2}+y^{2}=2 c \quad [/latex] (Represents family of circles)

question: Question 3 Let H(z) be the z-transform of a real-valued discrete-time signal h[n]. If [latex]P(z)=H(z)H\left (\frac{1}{z} \right )[/latex] has a zero at [latex]z=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}j[/latex], and P(z) has a total of four zeros, which one of the following plots represents all the zeros correctly?
solution: [latex]P(Z)=H(Z)H\left ( \frac{1}{Z} \right )[/latex] (i) [latex]h(n)[/latex] is real. Som [latex]p(n)[/latex] will be also real (ii) [latex]P(z)=P(z^{-1})[/latex] From (i) : if [latex]z_1[/latex] is a zero of [latex]P(z)[/latex], then [latex]z_1^*[/latex] will be also a zero of [latex]P(z)[/latex]. From (ii): If [latex]z_1[/latex] is a zero of [latex]P(z)[/latex], then [latex]\frac{1}{z_1}[/latex] will be also a zero of [latex]P(z)[/latex]. So, the 4 zeros are, [latex]\begin{aligned} z_1&= \frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}j\\ z_2&= z_1^*=\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2}j\\ z_3&=\frac{1}{z_1}=\frac{1}{\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2}j}=1-j \\ z_4&=\left ( \frac{1}{z_1} \right )^*=z_3^*=1+j \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 4 Consider the two-port resistive network shown in the figure. When an excitation of 5 V is applied across Port 1, and Port 2 is shorted, the current through the short circuit at Port 2 is measured to be 1 A (see (a) in the figure). Now, if an excitation of 5 V is applied across Port 2, and Port 1 is shorted (see(b) in the figure), what is the current through the short circuit at Port 1?
solution: According to reciprocity theorem, In a linear bilateral single source network the ratio of response to excitation remains the same even after their positions get interchanged. [latex] \therefore \quad \frac{I}{5}=\frac{1}{5} \Rightarrow I=1 \mathrm{A}[/latex]

question: Question 5 Let Y(s) be the unit-step response of a causal system having a transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{3-s}{(s+1)(s+3)}[/latex] that is, [latex]Y(s)=\frac{G(s)}{s}[/latex]. The forced response of the system is
solution: Given, [latex]\quad G(s)=\frac{3-s}{(s+1)(s+3)} [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad Y(s)=\frac{G(s)}{s}=\frac{3-s}{s(s+1)(s+3)} [/latex] Using partial fractions, we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} Y(s)&=\frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{(s+1)}+\frac{C}{(s+3)} \\ A\left(s^{2}+4 s+3\right)&+B\left(s^{2}+3 s\right)+C\left(s^{2}+s\right)=3-s \\ A+B+C&=0\\ 4 A+3 B+C&=-1 \\ \text{and }3 A&=3 \\ \text{Therefore, }&\text{we get,}\\ A=1, B&=-2 \text { and } C=1\\ \text{So, }\quad Y(s)&=\frac{1}{s}-\frac{2}{(s+1)}+\frac{1}{(s+3)} \\ \text{and}\quad \mathrm{y}(t)&=u(t)-2 e^{-t} u(t)+e^{-3 t} u(t) \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Forced response, [latex] y_{t}(t)=u(t) \Rightarrow \text { option }(D)[/latex]

question: Question 6 For an LTI system, the Bode plot for its gain is as illustrated in the figure shown. The number of system poles [latex]N_p[/latex] and the number of system zeros [latex]N_z[/latex] in the frequency range [latex]1Hz\leq f\leq 10^7Hz[/latex] is
solution: Number of poles [latex](N_{P})[/latex]= 6 Number of zeros [latex](N_{Z})[/latex] = 3

question: Question 7 A linear Hamming code is used to map 4-bit messages to 7-bit codewords. The encoder mapping is linear. If the message 0001 is mapped to the codeword 0000111, and the message 0011 is mapped to the codeword 1100110, then the message 0010 is mapped to
Question 8 Which one of the following options describes correctly the equilibrium band diagram at T=300 K of a Silicon [latex]pnp^+p^{++}[/latex] configuration shown in the figure?
Question 9 The correct circuit representation of the structure shown in the figure is

Question 10 The figure shows the high-frequency C-V curve of a MOS capacitor (at T = 300 K) with [latex]\Phi _{ms}=0V[/latex] and no oxide charges. The flat-band, inversion, and accumulation conditions are represented, respectively, by the points
solution: Since [latex]\phi_{ms}= 0[/latex], the MOS-capacitor is ideal. Point P Represents accumulation Point Q Represents flat band Point R Represents Inversion

question: Question 11 What is the electric flux ([latex]\int \vec{E}\cdot d\hat{a}[/latex]) through a quarter-cylinder of height H (as shown in the figure) due to an infinitely long line charge along the axis of the cylinder with a charge density of Q?
solution: Electric field intensity [latex](\vec{E})[/latex] at '[latex]\rho[/latex]' distance due to infinite long line having line charge density Q is [latex] \begin{aligned} \vec{E} &=\frac{Q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} \rho} \hat{a}_{\rho} \\ \int \vec{E} \cdot \vec{da} &=\iint \frac{Q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0} \rho} \hat{a}_{p} \cdot \rho d \phi d z \hat{a}_{\rho} \\ &=\frac{Q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \int_{<\pi / 2>} d \phi \int_{z=0}^{H} d z \\ &=\frac{Q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right) H=\frac{H Q}{4 \varepsilon_{0}} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 13 A standard CMOS inverter is designed with equal rise and fall times ([latex]\beta _n=\beta _p[/latex]). If the width of the pMOS transistor in the inverter is increased, what would be the effect on the LOW noise margin ([latex]NM_L[/latex]) and the HIGH noise margin [latex]NM_H[/latex]?
solution:
Making PMOS wider, shifts input transition point 
[latex](V_{IT})[/latex] towards [latex]V_{DD}[/latex] Making NMOS wider, shifts input transition point 
[latex](V_{IT})[/latex] towards zero. So, as PMOS made wider, NML increases and NMH 
decreases.

options.D: No change in the noise margins.

question: Question 14 In the circuit shown, what are the values of F for EN=0 and EN=1, respectively?
solution: When [latex]E N=0 [/latex] [latex] x_{1}=(\overline{D \cdot 0})=1 \Rightarrow [/latex] PMOS is in OFF state [latex] x_{2}=(\overline{1+D})=0 \Rightarrow[/latex] NMOS is in OFF state Both the transistors are in OFF state, which offers high impedance. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { When } E N=1: x_{1}&=(\overline{D \cdot 1})=\bar{D} \\ x_{2}&=(\overline{0+D})=\bar{D} \\ F &=D \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 15 In the circuit shown, A and B are the inputs and Fis the output. What is the functionality of the circuit?
solution: So, the given logic circuit acts as an XNOR gate

question: Question 16 The value of the contour integral [latex]\frac{1}{2 \pi j}\oint \left (z+\frac{1}{z} \right )^2 dz[/latex] evaluated over the unit circle |z|=1 is ______
solution: [latex]\frac{1}{2 \pi j} \oint\left(z+\frac{1}{z}\right)^{2} d z \text { where } C \text { is }|z|=1[/latex] [latex] I=\frac{1}{2 \pi j} \int_{c}^{\left(z^{2}+1\right)^{2}} d z[/latex] z=0 lies inside the circle, [latex] \begin{aligned} I &=\frac{1}{2 \pi j}\left[\frac{2 \pi j}{1 !} \frac{d}{d z}\left(z^{2}+1\right)^{2}\right]_{2=0} \\ &=\left[\frac{d}{d z}\left(z^{2}+1\right)^{2}\right]_{z=0} \\ &=\left[2\left(z^{2}+1\right) \times 2 z\right]_{z=0}=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 17 The number of distinct eigenvalues of the matrix [latex]\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 2 & 3 &3 \\ 0& 1 & 1 & 1\\ 0 & 0 & 3 &3 \\ 0&0 & 0 &2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] is equal to ____
solution: [latex]A=\left[\begin{array}{llll} 2 & 2 & 3 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 3 & 3 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 2 \end{array}\right][/latex] Eigen values are 2,1,3,2 Distinct eigen values are 2,1,3[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Number of distinct eigen values =3

question: Question 18 If X and Y are random variables such that E[2X+Y]=0 and E[X+2Y]=33, then E[X]+E[Y]=________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} E[2 X+Y] &=0 \text { and } E[X+2 Y]=33 \\ \text { then, } \quad 2 E[X]+E[Y] &=0 \text { and } E[X]+2 E[Y]=33 \\ 3 E[X]+3 E[Y] &=0+33=33 \\ E[X]+E[Y] &=11 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 19 The value of the integral [latex]\int_{0}^{\pi}\int_{y}^{\pi}\frac{sinx}{x}dxdy[/latex], is equal to ______
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} x=y ; x=\pi\\ y=O; y = \pi \end{array}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\int_{0}^{\pi} \int_{y}^{\pi} \frac{\sin x}{x} d x d y=\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{\sin x}{x}(y)_{0}^{x} d x \\ =\int_{0}^{\pi} \frac{\sin x}{x}(x) d x \\ =\int_{0}^{\pi} \sin x d x=(-\cos x)_{0}^{\pi} \\ =-\cos \pi+\cos 0=1+1=2 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 20 Let Z be an exponential random variable with mean 1. That is, the cumulative distribution function of Z is given by [latex]F_z(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1-e^{-x} & if & x\geq 0\\ 0 & if & x \lt 0 \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] Then [latex]Pr(Z\gt 2|Z \gt 1)[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places, is equal to ______
solution: Required probability [latex] \begin{aligned} =&P(2 \gt 2) \cap(z \gt 1)]=\frac{P(z \gt 2]}{P[z \gt 1]} \\ P(z \gt 1] &=1-e^{-2} \Rightarrow P(z \gt 2)=e^{-2} \\ P(z \leq 2)=&1-e^{-1} \Rightarrow P(z \gt 1)=e^{-1} \end{aligned}[/latex] So.Required probability [latex] =\frac{e^{-2}}{e^{-1}}=e^{-1} \simeq 0.37[/latex]

question: Question 21 Consider the signal [latex]f(t)=1+2cos(\pi t)+3sin\left ( \frac{2 \pi}{3}t \right )+4cos\left (\frac{\pi}{2}t+\frac{\pi}{4} \right )[/latex], where t is in seconds. Its fundamental time period, in seconds, is ____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(t)=1+2 \cos (\pi t)&+3 \sin \left(\frac{2 \pi}{3} t\right)+4 \cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2} t+\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \\ \omega_{1}&=\pi \\ \omega_{2}&=\frac{2 \pi}{3} \\ \omega_{3}&=\frac{\pi}{2} \\ \omega_{0}&=G C D\left(\pi, \frac{2 \pi}{3}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)=\frac{\pi}{6} \end{aligned}[/latex] Fundamental period, [latex] N=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega_{0}}=\frac{2 \pi}{(\pi / 6)}=12[/latex]

question: Question 22 The baseband signal m(t) shown in the figure is phase-modulated to generate the PM signal [latex]\varphi (t)=2cos(2 \pi f_c t+km(t))[/latex]. The time t on the x-axis in the figure is in milliseconds. If the carrier frequency is [latex]f_c[/latex]=50kHz and [latex]k=10 \pi[/latex], then the ratio of the minimum instantaneous frequency (in kHz) to the maximum instantaneous frequency (in kHz) is  __________  (rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f_i&=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\frac{d\theta (t)}{dt}= \\ &=f_c+\frac{k}{2 \pi}\frac{dm (t)}{dt} \\ &=f_c+5\frac{dm (t)}{dt} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} f_{i(min)}&=50kHz-(5 \times 1000Hz)=45kHz\\ f_{i(max)}&=50kHz+(5 \times 2000Hz)=60kHz\\ \frac{f_{i(min)}}{f_{i(max)}}&=\frac{45}{60}=0.75 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 23 Radiation resistance of a small dipole current element of length l at a frequency of 3 GHz is 3 ohms. If the length is changed by 1%, then the percentage change in the radiation resistance, rounded off to two decimal places, is _____ %.
solution: Radiation resistance of a small dipole current  element of length 'I' is [latex] \begin{array}{l} R_{\mathrm{rad}}=80 \pi^{2}\left(\frac{l}{\lambda}\right)^{2} \Rightarrow R \propto l^{2} \\ \frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}=\left(\frac{l_{2}}{l_{1}}\right)^{2} \end{array}[/latex] If length is changed by 1% then percentage change in the radiation resistance. [latex] \frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}}=\left(\frac{1.01 l}{l}\right)^{2}=1.0201[/latex] [latex] \text { Percentage change in radiation resistance } [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{R_{2}-R_{1}}{R_{1}} \times 100 \\ =0.0201 \times 100=2.01 \% \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 24 In thecircuit shown, [latex]V_s[/latex] is a square wave of period T with maximum and minimum values of 8 V and -10 V, respectively.  Assume that the diode is ideal and [latex]R_1=R_2=50\Omega[/latex]. The average value of [latex]V_L[/latex] is____ volts (rounded off to 1 decimal place).
solution: When [latex]V_{s}=8 \mathrm{V} \Rightarrow [/latex]diode is in reverse bias [latex] V_{L}=\frac{8 \times 50}{50+50}=4 \mathrm{V}[/latex] If [latex]V_{s}=-10 \mathrm{V},[/latex] diode is in forward bias Average value of [latex]V_{L}=\frac{\text { Area }}{\text { Time period }} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{4 \times 0.5 T+(-10) \times 0.5 T}{T}=-3 V[/latex]

question: Question 25 In the circuit shown, the clock frequency, i.e., the frequency of the Clk signal, is 12?kHz. The frequency of the signal at [latex]Q_2[/latex] is____ kHz.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} M O D &=3 \\ f_{Q 2} &=\frac{f_{c \mid k}}{3}=\frac{12}{3} k H z=4 k H z \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 26 Consider a differentiable function [latex]f(x)[/latex] on the set of real numbers such that [latex]f(-1)=0[/latex] and [latex]f'(x)\leq 2[/latex]. Given these conditions, which one of the following inequalities is necessarily true for all [latex]x\in [-2,2][/latex]?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given that, }&\left|f^{\prime}(x)\right| \leq 2 ; &f(-1)=0 \\ &-2 \leq f^{\prime}(x) \leq 2\\ x \in[-2,2] &\rightarrow 2 \leq x \leq 2 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \therefore [/latex] By applying mean value theorem in [-1,2] [latex] \begin{array}{l} -2 \leq f^{\prime}(x) \leq 2 \\ -2 \leq \frac{f(2)-f(-1)}{2-(-1)} \leq 2 \\ -2 \leq \frac{f(2)-f(-1)}{3} \leq 2 \\ -6 \leq f(2)-0 \leq 6 \\ -6 \leq f(2) \leq 6 \end{array}[/latex] It is satisfied by only option (B).

question: Question 27 Consider the line integral [latex]\int _c (xdy-ydx)[/latex] the integral being taken in a counterclockwise direction over the closed curve C that forms the boundary of the region R shown in the figure below. The region R is the area enclosed by the union of a 2x3 rectangle and a semi-circle of radius 1. The line integral evaluates to
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \text { Given, } \int-y d x+x d y \\ \qquad \begin{aligned} \text { here, } \quad F_{1}&=-y \text { and } \frac{\partial F_{1}}{\partial y}=-1 \\ F_{2} &=x \text { and } \frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial x}=1 \\ \therefore \int F_{1} d x+F_{2} d y &=\iint\left(\frac{\partial F_{2}}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial F_{1}}{\partial y}\right) d x d y \\ \int-y d x+x d y &=\iint 1-(-1) d x d y \\ &=2( \text { Area of region R}) \\ &=2\left(6+\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=12+\pi \end{aligned} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 28 Consider a six-point decimation-in-time Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) algorithm, for which the signal-flow graph corresponding to X[1] is shown in the figure. Let [latex]W_6=exp\left ( -\frac{j2 \pi}{6} \right )[/latex]. In the figure, what should be the values of the coefficients [latex]a_1,a_2,a_3[/latex] in terms of [latex]W_6[/latex] so that X[1] is obtained correctly?
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} X(k)=\sum_{n=0}^{N-1} x(n) e^{-j \frac{2 \pi}{N} k n} \\ X(1)=\sum_{n=0}^{5} x(n) W_{6}^{n}\\ =x(0)+x(1) W_{6}+x(2) M_{6}^{2}+x(3) n_{6}^{3}+x(4) M_{6}^{4}+x(5) n_{6}^{5} \ldots(i) \\ \end{array}[/latex] From the given flow graph, [latex] X(k)=[x(0)-x(3)] a_{1}+[x(1)-x(4)] a_{2}+[x(2)-x(5)] a_{3} [/latex] By comparing equations (i) and (ii), we get. [latex] a_{1}=1, a_{2}=W_{6}, a_{3}=W_{6}^{2}[/latex]

question: Question 29 It is desired to find a three-tap causal filter which gives zero signal as an output to an input of the form [latex]x[n]=c_1 \; exp\left ( -\frac{j\pi n}{2} \right )+c_2 \; exp\left ( \frac{j\pi n}{2} \right )[/latex] where [latex]c_1 \; and \; c_2[/latex] are arbitrary real numbers. The desired three-tap filter is given by [latex]h[0]=1,\;\; h[1]=a, \;\;h[2]=b[/latex] and [latex]h[n]=0\;\; for \; n \lt 0 \; or \; n\gt 2[/latex] What are the values of the filter taps a and b if the output is y[n]=0 for all n, when x[n] is as given above?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x(n) &=c_{1} e^{-j \frac{\pi}{2} n}+c_{2} e^{j \frac{\pi}{2} n} \\ \omega_{0} &=\frac{\pi}{2} \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \\ H\left(e^{i \omega}\right) &=1+a e^{-j \omega}+b e^{-j 2 \omega}\\ \text{To get }y(n)=0& \\ H\left(e^{j \omega_{o}}\right)&=\left.H\left(e^{j \omega}\right)\right|_{\omega=\frac{\pi}{2}}=0\\ 1+a e^{-i \frac{\pi}{2}}+b e^{-i 2 \frac{\pi}{2}}&=0 \\ 1-j a-b&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] From the given options, a=0 and b=1

question: Question 30 In the circuit shown, if [latex]v(t)=2sin(1000t)[/latex] volts, [latex]R=1k\Omega[/latex] and [latex]R=C=1\mu F[/latex], then the steady-state current [latex]i(t)[/latex], in milliamperes (mA), is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Here,}X_{C}&=\frac{1}{\omega C}=\frac{1}{10^{3} \times 10^{-6}}=\frac{1}{10^{-3}}\\ x_{C} &=10^{3} \Omega \\ R &=10^{3} \Omega \quad \text { (Given) } \\ v(t) &=2 \sin 1000 t \vee=2 \angle 0^{\circ} \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex] Redrawing the given network, we get, As the bridge is balanced, it can be redrawn as [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad Y_{e q} &=Y_{1}+Y_{2} \\ &=\frac{3}{2} R+\frac{1}{-2 j X_{C}} \\ &=\frac{3}{2} \times 10^{-3}+j \frac{1}{2} \times 10^{-3} \\ \therefore \quad i(t) &=(t) \times Y_{\mathrm{eq}}=2 \angle 0^{\circ}\left[\frac{3}{2}+j \frac{1}{2}\right] \mathrm{m} \mathrm{A} \\ &=(3+j 1) \mathrm{mA} \\ &=3 \sin (1000 t)+\cos (1000 t) \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 31 Consider a causal second-order system with the transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{1+2s+s^2}[/latex] with a unit-step [latex]R(s)=\frac{1}{s}[/latex] as an input. Let C(s) be the corresponding output. The time taken by the system output c(t) to reach 94% of its steady-state value [latex]\lim_{t \to \infty }c(t)[/latex], rounded off to two decimal places, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} G(s)&=\frac{1}{s^{2}+2 s+1}=\frac{1}{(s+1)^{2}} \\ R(s)&=\frac{1}{s} \\ \alpha (s)&=G(s) R(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Using partial fraction expansion, we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} C(s) & =\frac{A}{s}+\frac{B}{(s+1)}+\frac{C}{(s+1)^{2}} \\ A\left(s^{2}+2 s+1\right)&+B\left(s^{2}+s\right)+C s=1 \\ A&=1 \\ A+B & =0 \Rightarrow B=-1 \\ 2 A+B+C & =0 \Rightarrow C=-1 \\ \therefore \quad C(s) & =\frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{(s+1)}-\frac{1}{(s+1)^{2}} \\ \text{and}\quad c(t) & =\left(1-e^{-t}-t e^{-t}\right) u(t) \\ \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} c(t) & =1 \end{aligned}[/latex] In order to reach 94 % of its steady-state value, [latex] \left(1-e^{-t}-t e^{-t}\right)=0.94[/latex] By trial and error, we get, [latex] t \approx 4.50 \mathrm{sec}[/latex]

question: Question 32 The block diagram of a system is illustrated in the figure shown, where X(s) is the input and Y(s) is the output. The transfer function [latex]H(s)=\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}[/latex] is
solution:
Using block diagram reduction, we get, [latex]
\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=H(s)=\frac{s^{2}+1}{s^{3}+2 s^{2}+s+1}[/latex]

question: Question 33 Let the state-space representation of an LTI system be [latex]\dot{x}(t)=Ax(t)+Bu(t)[/latex],  [latex]\dot{y}(t)=Cx(t)+du(t)[/latex]  where A, B, C are matrices, d is a scalar, u(t) is the input to the system, and y(t) is its output. Let [latex]B=[0\;0\;1]^T[/latex] and d=0. Which one of the following options for A and C will ensure that the transfer function of this LTI system is [latex]H(s)=\frac{1}{s^3+3s^2+2s+1}[/latex]?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} X(t) &=A x(t)+B u(t) \\ y(t) &=C x(t) \\ B &=\left[\begin{array}{l} 0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \\ \frac{\gamma(s)}{U(s)} &=\\ \frac{\gamma(s)}{X_{1}(s)} \times \frac{X_{1}(s)}{U(s)}=& 1 \times \frac{1}{s^{3}+3 s^{2}+2 s+1} \\ x_{1}(s)\left(s^{3}+3 s^{2}+2 s+1\right]&=U(s) \\ x_{2} &=\dot{x}_{1}(t) \\ x_{2}(s) &=s x_{1}(s) \\ x_{3} &=\dot{x}_{2}(t) \\ \Rightarrow \quad x_{3}(s) &=s x_{2}(s)=s^{2} X_{1}(s) \\ \text { So, } \quad s x_{3}(s) &=-x_{1}(s)-2 x_{2}(s)-3 x_{3}(s)+u(s) \\ \dot{x}_{3}(t) &=-x_{1}(t)-2 r_{2}(t)-3 x_{3}(t)+u(t) \\ y(t) &=x_{1}(t) \\ \dot{x}(t) &=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ -1 & -2 & -3\end{array}\right] x(t)+\left[\begin{array}{l}0 \\ 0 \\ 1\end{array}\right] u(t) \\ y(t) &=[1 \quad 0 \quad 0] x(t) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 34 A single bit, equally likely to be 0 and 1, is to be sent across an additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel with power spectral density [latex]N_0/2[/latex]. Binary signaling, with [latex]0\rightarrow p(t)[/latex] and [latex]1\rightarrow q(t)[/latex], is used for the transmission, along with an optimal receiver that minimizes the bit-error probability. Let [latex]\varphi _1(t),\varphi _2(t)[/latex] form an orthonormal signal set. If we choose [latex]p(t)=\varphi _1(t)\; and \; q(t)=-\varphi _2(t)[/latex], we would obtain a certain bit-error probability [latex]P_b[/latex]. If we keep [latex]p(t)=\varphi _1(t)[/latex], but take [latex]q(t)=\sqrt{E}\varphi _2(t)[/latex], for what value of E would we obtain the same bit-error probability [latex]P_b[/latex]?
solution: [latex]\text { When } p(t)=\phi_{1}(t) \text { and } q(t)=-\phi_{1}(t) [/latex] [latex] d_{\min }=2[/latex] [latex] \text { When } p(t)=\phi_{1}(t) \text { and } q(t)=-\sqrt{E}\phi_{2}(t)[/latex] [latex] d_{\min }=\sqrt{(\sqrt{E})^{2}+1}=\sqrt{E+1}[/latex] To obtain same bit-error probability, [latex]\sigma_{\text {min }} [/latex] should be same. [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { So, } \quad \sqrt{E+1} &=2 \\ E &=3 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 The quantum efficiency ([latex]\eta[/latex]) and responsivity (R) at a wavelength [latex]\lambda (in \; \mu m)[/latex] in a p-i-n photodetector are related by
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta&=\frac{I_{\text {out }}}{q} \times \frac{h f}{P_{\text {in }}} \\ R&=\frac{I_{\text {out }}}{P_{\text {in }}}\\ \text{So, }\quad R&=\eta \times \frac{q}{h f}=\eta \times \frac{q \lambda}{h c} \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] If [latex]\lambda[/latex] is given in [latex]\mu \mathrm{m},[/latex] then [latex] \begin{aligned} R &=\eta \lambda \times \frac{q \times 10^{-6}}{h c} \\ \frac{h c}{q \times 10^{-6}} & \simeq 1.24\\ \text{So, }\quad R&=\frac{\eta \lambda}{1.24} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 Two identical copper wires W1 and W2, placed in parallel as shown in the figure, carry currents I and 2I, respectively, in opposite directions. If the two wires are separated by a distance of 4r, then the magnitude of the magnetic field [latex]\vec{B}[/latex] between the wires at a distance r from W1 is
solution: Magnetic flux density [latex](\vec{B})[/latex] at r distance due to infinite line carrying current I is [latex]|\vec{B}|=\frac{\mu_{0} I}{2 \pi \rho} .[/latex] [latex] \vec{B} [/latex] at r distance due to [latex]W_{1}[/latex] wire [latex] =\left|\vec{B}_{1}\right|=\frac{\mu_{0} I}{2 \pi r}\qquad \ldots(i)[/latex] [latex] \vec{B} [/latex] at 3r distance due to [latex]W_{2}[/latex] wire [latex] =\left|\vec{B}_{2}\right|=\frac{\mu_{0}(2 I)}{2 \pi(3 r)}\qquad \ldots(ii)[/latex] From right hand thumb rule, [latex]\vec{B} [/latex] due to both lines add in between conductors. [latex] \begin{aligned} {So,}\qquad |\vec{B}|&=\left|\vec{B}_{1}\right|+\left|\vec{B}_{2}\right|\\ \therefore \qquad |\vec{B}|&=\frac{\mu_{0} I}{2 \pi r}+\frac{2 \mu_{0} I}{6 \pi r}=\frac{5 \mu_{0} I}{6 \pi r} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 37 The dispersion equation of a waveguide,which relates the wavenumber kto the frequency [latex]\omega[/latex], is [latex]k(\omega) =(1/c)\sqrt{\omega ^2 -{\omega _0}^2}[/latex] where the speed of light [latex]c=3 \times 10^8[/latex] m/s, and [latex]\omega_0[/latex] is a constant.  If the group velocity is [latex]2 \times 10^8[/latex] m/s, then the phase velocity is
solution: By definition [latex]v_{p}=\frac{\omega}{\beta}=\frac{\omega}{k} [/latex] where, [latex]k(\omega)=\left(\frac{1}{c}\right) \sqrt{\omega^{2}-\omega_{0}^{2}} \quad [/latex](given) [latex] \therefore v_{p}=\frac{c}{\sqrt{1-\left(\frac{\omega_{0}}{\omega}\right)^{2}}}[/latex] by definition, [latex] \begin{aligned} v_{g} &=\frac{d \omega}{d \beta}=\frac{d \omega}{d k} \\ &=\frac{d k}{d \omega}=\frac{1}{c} \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{\omega^{2}-\omega_{0}^{2}}} \times 2 \omega \\ \text{or}\quad v_{g} &=c \sqrt{1-\left(\frac{\omega_{0}}{\omega}\right)^{2}}\\ \because \quad v_{p} \cdot v_{g} &=c^{2} \\ \therefore \quad v_{p} &=\frac{c^{2}}{v_{g}}=\frac{\left(3 \times 10^{8}\right)^{2}}{2 \times 10^{8}} \\ &=4.5 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 In the circuit shown, the breakdown voltage and the maximum current of the Zener diode are 20 V and 60 mA, respectively. The values of [latex]R_1 \; and \; R_L[/latex] are [latex]200\Omega \; and \; 1k\Omega[/latex], respectively. What is the range of [latex]V_i[/latex] that will maintain the Zener diode in the 'on' state?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{z} &=20 \mathrm{V} \\ I_{z \max } &=60 \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex] Set zener diode be OFF [latex] V_{o}=\frac{V_{i} \times 1}{0.2+1}=\frac{V_{i}}{1.2}[/latex] Zener diode can become ON i.e. it goes into breakdown, when [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{V_{i}}{1.2} & \gt 20 \mathrm{V} \\ V_{i} & \gt 24 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex] When Zener diode is in breakdown region, [latex] \begin{array}{l} I_{1}=\frac{V_{i}-20}{0.2 \mathrm{k} \Omega}=\frac{V_{i}-20}{0.2} \mathrm{mA}\\ I_{L}=\frac{V_{0}}{R_{L}}=\frac{20}{1 \mathrm{k} \Omega}=20 \mathrm{mA} \\ I_{z}=I_{1}-I_{L}=\frac{V_{i}-20}{0.2}-20 \end{array}[/latex] For safe operation, [latex]I_{z} \leq I_{z \max } [/latex] [latex] \frac{V_{i}-20}{0.2}-20 \leq 60[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow V_{i} \leq 36 \mathrm{V}[/latex] Hence, [latex]24 \lt V_{i} \lt 36 V[/latex]

question: Question 39 The state transition diagram for the circuit shown is
solution: When [latex] A=0, Q_{n+1}=1 [/latex] When  [latex]A=1, Q_{n+1}=\bar{Q}_{n} [/latex] So, the correct state transition diagram is,

question: Question 40 In the circuits shown, the threshold voltage of each Nmos transistor is 0.6 V. Ignoring the effect of channel length modulation and body bias, the values of Vout1 and Vout2, respectively, in volts, are
solution: [latex]V_{\text {out } 1}=3-0.6-0.6=1.8 \mathrm{V}[/latex]

question: Question 41 The RC circuit shown below has a variable resistance R(t) given  by the following expression: [latex]R(t)=R_0\left ( 1-\frac{t}{T} \right ) \; for \;0\leq t \lt T[/latex] where [latex]R_0=1\Omega[/latex], and C=1F. We are also given that [latex]T=3R_0C[/latex] and the source voltage is [latex]V_s=1V[/latex]. If the current at time t=0 is 1A, then the current I(t), in amperes, at time t=T/2 is ___________(rounded off to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} T=3 R_{0} C=3 \mathrm{sec} \\ R(t)=\left(1-\frac{t}{3}\right) ; 0 \leq t \leq 3 \mathrm{sec} \end{array}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} R(t) i(t)+\frac{1}{C} \int i(t) d t&=1 \\ \left(1-\frac{t}{3}\right) i(t)+\int i(t) d t&=1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Differentiating both sides, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \left(1-\frac{t}{3}\right) \frac{d i}{d t}-\frac{i}{3}+i &=0 \\ (3-t) \frac{d i}{d t}+2 i &=0 \\ \frac{d i}{i} &=-\frac{2}{(3-t)} d t \end{aligned}[/latex] Integrating on both sides, we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} \ln (i)&=2 \ln (3-t)+\ln (c)\\ i(t)&=c(3-t)^{2} ; t \geq 0\\ \text{Given that,} i(0)&=1 A.\\ \text{So,}\quad c(3-0)^{2} &=1 \mathrm{A} \\ c &=\frac{1}{9} \mathrm{A} \\ i(t) &=\frac{1}{9}(3-t)^{2} \mathrm{A}\\ \text{At }t&=\frac{T}{2}=1.5 \mathrm{sec} \\ i(1.5)&=\frac{1}{9}(1.5)^{2}=0.25 A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 42 Consider a unity feedback system, as in the figure shown, with an integral compensator [latex]\frac{K}{s}[/latex] and open-loop transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s^2+3s+2}[/latex] where [latex]k \gt 0[/latex]. The positive value of K for which there are exactly two poles of the unity feedback system on the [latex]j\omega[/latex] axis is equal to ______ (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\frac{Y(s)}{X(s)}=\frac{K}{s^{3}+3 s^{2}+2 s+K} [/latex] Two poles of this system lie the system is moro: System is marginally stable. [latex] \qquad k_{\text{mar}}=3 \times 2=6[/latex]

question: Question 43 Consider the homogeneous ordinary differential equation [latex]x^2\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}-3x\frac{dy}{dx}+3y=0, \; x \gt 0[/latex] with y(x) as a generalsolution. Given that y(1)=1 and y(2)=14 the value of y(1.5), rounded off to two decimal places, is ______.

Question 44 Let h[n] be a length-7 discrete-time finite impulse response filter, given by h[0]=4, h[1]=3,  h[2]=2,  h[3]=1, h[-1]=-3,  h[-2]=-2,  h[-3]=-1, and h[n] is zero for [latex]|n|\geq 4[/latex]. A length-3 finite impulse response approximation g[n] of g[n] has to be obtained such that [latex]E(h,g)=\int_{-\pi}^{\pi}|H(e^{j\omega })-G(e^{j\omega })|^2d\omega[/latex] is minimized, where  [latex]H(e^{j\omega })[/latex] and [latex]G(e^{j\omega })[/latex] are the discrete-time Fourier transforms of h[n] and g[n], respectively. For the filter that minimizes E(h,g), the value of 10g[-1]+g[1], rounded off to 2 decimal places, is ________
solution: From Parseval's theorem, [latex] \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}|x[n]|^{2}=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi}\left|X\left(e^{j \omega}\right)\right|^{2} d \omega[/latex] So, [latex] \int_{-\pi}^{\pi}\left|H\left(e^{j \omega}\right)-G\left(e^{j \omega}\right)\right|^{2} d \omega=2 \pi \sum_{n=-3}^{3}|h(n)-g(n)|^{2} [/latex] The solution of g(n) that minimizes E(h, g) also minimizes [latex]\sum_{n=-3}^{3}|h(n)-g(n)|^{2} [/latex] [latex] \sum_{n=-3}^{3}|h(n)-g(n)|^{2}[/latex] [latex] =|4-g(0)|^{2}+|3-g(1)|^{2}+|-3-g(-1)|^{2}+10 [/latex] The solution of g(n) that minimizes the above equation is [latex] g(n)=(-3,4,3\}[/latex] [latex] So, 10 g(-1)+g(1)=10(-3)+3=-27[/latex]

question: Question 45 Let a random process Y(t) be described as Y(t)=h(t)*X(t)+Z(t), where X(t) is a white noise process with power spectral density [latex]S_X(f)=5[/latex] W/Hz. The filter h(t) has a magnitude response given by |H(f)|=0.5 for [latex]-5\leq f\leq 5[/latex], and zero elsewhere. Z(t) is a  stationary random process, uncorrelated with X(t), with power spectral density as shown in the figure. The power in Y(t), in watts, is equal to ________ W (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Let, } \quad X_{1}(t) &=h(t) * X(t) \\ S_{X 1}(f) &=|H(f)|^{2} S_{X}(f) \end{aligned}[/latex] Given that, Z(t) and X(t) are uncorrelated [latex] \begin{aligned} & \text{So,}\quad S_{y}(f)=S_{X 1}(f)+S_{z}(f)\\ & \text{Power in }\mathrm{y}(t) \\ P_{Y}&=\left[\text { Area under } S_{X 1}(f)\right]+\left[\text { Area under } S_{z}(f)\right] \\ &=(10 \times 1.25)+(5 \times 1)=17.5 \mathrm{W} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 A voice signal m(t) is in the frequency range 5 kHz to 15 kHz. The signal is amplitude-modulated to generate an AM signal [latex]f(t)=A(1+m(t))cos 2\pi f_c t[/latex], where [latex]f_c[/latex]=600kHz. The AM signal f(t) is to be digitized and archived. This is done by first sampling f(t) at 1.2 times the Nyquist frequency, and then quantizing each sample using a 256-level quantizer. Finally, each quantized sample is binary coded using K bits, where K is the minimum number of bits required for the encoding. The rate, in Megabits per second (rounded off to 2 decimal places), of the resulting stream of coded bits is _______ Mbps.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Nyquist rate } &=2 \times 615 \mathrm{kHz} \\ &=1230 \mathrm{kHz}=1.23 \mathrm{MHz} \\ f_{s} &=1.2 \times 1.23=1.476 \mathrm{MHz} \\ \text { Bits/sample }, n &=\log _{2}(256)=8 \\ \text { So, } \quad A_{D} &=n f_{s}=8 \times 1.476 \\ &=11.808 \simeq 11.81 \mathrm{Mbps} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 47 A random variable X takes values  -1 and +1 with probabilities 0.2 and 0.8, respectively. It is transmitted across a channel which adds noise N, so that the random variable at the channel output is Y=X+N. The noise N is independent of X, and is uniformly distributed over the interval [-2,2]. The receiver makes a decision [latex]\hat{X}=\left\{\begin{matrix} -1 & if & Y\leq \theta \\ +1& if & Y> \theta \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] where the threshold [latex]\theta \in [-1,1][/latex] is chosen so as to minimize the probability of error [latex]Pr[\hat{X}\neq X][/latex]. The minimum probability of error, rounded off to 1 decimal place, is ______.
solution: MAP criteria should be used to minimise the probability of error. [latex] \begin{array}{c} f_{Y}(y \mid+1) P(+1) \sum_{-1}^{+1} f_{Y}(y \mid-1) F(-1) \\ P(+1)=0.80 \text { and } P(-1)=0.20 \end{array}[/latex] [latex]P_{\theta(m \text { in })}=[/latex] Shaded area [latex]=2 \times \frac{1}{20}=0.10[/latex]

question: Question 48 A Germanium sample of dimensions 1cmx1cm is illuminated with a 20 mW, 600 nm laser light source as shown in the figure. The illuminated sample surface has a 100 nm of loss-less Silicon dioxide layer that reflects one-fourth of the incident light. From the remaining light, one-third of the power is reflected from the Silicon dioxide-Germanium interface, one-third is absorbed in the Germanium layer, and one-third is transmitted through the other side of the sample. If the absorption coefficient of Germanium at 600 nm is [latex]3 \times 10^4 cm^{-1}[/latex] and the bandgap is 0.66 eV, the thickness of the Germanium layer, rounded off to 3 decimal places, is ______ [latex]\mu m[/latex].
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{\text {absorbed }} &=P_{\text {incident }}\left(1-e^{-\alpha T}\right) \\ \frac{1}{3} &=\frac{2}{3}\left(1-e^{-\alpha T}\right) \\ \frac{2}{3} e^{-\alpha T} &=\frac{1}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] where [latex]\alpha=3 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{cm}^{-1}[/latex], absorption coefficient of Ge sample. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad T &=\frac{1}{\alpha} \ln (2)=\frac{1}{3 \times 10^{4}} \ln (2) \mathrm{cm} \\ &=0.231 \mu \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 49 In an ideal pn junction with an ideality factor of 1 at T=300 K, the magnitude of the reverse-bias voltage required to reach 75% of its reverse saturation current, rounded off to 2 decimal places, is ____mV. [[latex]k=1.38 \times 10^{-23}JK^{-1}[/latex], [latex]h=6.625 \times 10^{-34}J-s[/latex], [latex]q=1.602 \times 10^{-19}C[/latex]]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{T} &=\frac{k T}{q}=\frac{1.38 \times 10^{-23} \times 300}{1.602 \times 10^{-19}} \mathrm{V} \\ &=25.843 \mathrm{mV} \\ I &=I_{0}\left(e^{V / V_{T}}-1\right)=-\frac{3}{4} I_{0} \\ \Rightarrow\quad V &=V_{T} \ln 0.25=-35.83 \mathrm{mV} \\ V_{R} &=|V|=35.83 \mathrm{mV} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 Consider a long-channel MOSFET with a channel length 1 [latex]\mu m[/latex] and width 10 [latex]\mu m[/latex]. The device parameters are acceptor concentration [latex]N_A=5 \times 10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex], electron mobility [latex]\mu_n=800cm^2/V-s[/latex], oxide capacitance/area [latex]C_{ox}=3.45 \times 10^{-7}F/cm^{2}[/latex], threshold voltage [latex]V_T=0.7V[/latex]. The drain saturation current ([latex]I_{Dsat}[/latex]) for a gate voltage of 5 V is _____mA(rounded off to two decimal places). [latex][\varepsilon _0=8.854 \times 10^{-14}F/cm,\varepsilon _{Si}=11.9][/latex]
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{D(\text { sat })} &=\frac{1}{2} \mu_{n} C_{\text {ox }} \frac{W}{L}\left(V_{G S}-V_{T}\right)^{2} \\ &=\frac{1}{2} \times 800 \times 3.45 \times 10^{-7} \times \frac{10}{1}(5-0.7)^{2} \mathrm{A} \\ &=25.5162 \mathrm{mA} \simeq 25.52 \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 A rectangular waveguide of width w and height h has cut-off frequencies for [latex]TE_{10} \; and \;TE_{11}[/latex] modes in the ratio 1:2. The aspect ratio w/h, rounded off to two decimal places, is ___________
solution: [latex]f_{c m n}=\frac{c}{2} \sqrt{\left(\frac{m}{a}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{n}{b}\right)^{2}}[/latex] For TE mode [latex] f_{c10}=\frac{c}{2 w} \quad\ldots(i)[/latex] and For [latex]TE_{11}[/latex] mode. [latex] \begin{aligned} f_{c11} &=\frac{c}{2} \sqrt{\frac{1}{w}^{2}+\left(\frac{1}{h}\right)^{2}} &\ldots(i)\\ &=\frac{c}{2 w} \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{w}{h}\right)^{2}} &\ldots(ii)\\ \text{given}\quad\frac{f_{c10}}{f_{11}} &=\frac{1}{2} &\ldots(iii) \end{aligned}[/latex] put (i). (in) in (ii) [latex] \Rightarrow \frac{\frac{c}{2 w}}{\frac{c}{2 w} \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{w}{h}\right)^{2}}}=\frac{1}{2} \Rightarrow \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{w}{h}\right)^{2}}=2[/latex] On solving above equation, we get, [latex] \frac{w}{h}=\sqrt{3}=1.732[/latex]

question: Question 52 In the circuit shown, [latex]V_s[/latex] is a 10 V square wave of period, T=4 ms with R= 500[latex]\Omega[/latex] and C = 10 [latex]\mu F[/latex]. The capacitor is initially uncharged at t=0, and the diode is assumed to be ideal. The voltage across the capacitor ([latex]V_c[/latex]) at 3 ms is equal to ____ volts (rounded off to one decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau &=R C=500 \times 10 \times 10-6=5 \mathrm{m}_{8} \\ 0 \lt t \lt \frac{t}{2} \; :\; \;  v_{\mathrm{cap}} &=v_{f}+\left(v_{i}-v_{f}\right) e^{-t / \tau} \\ &=10+(0-10) e^{-t / \mathrm{Rc}}\\ \text{At }t&=2 \mathrm{msec,} \\ v_{\mathrm{cap}}&=10-10 e^{\frac{-2 \times 10^{-3}}{5 \times 10^{-3}}}\\ &=3.296 \mathrm{V} \simeq 3.3 \mathrm{V} \end{aligned}[/latex] For [latex]2 \mathrm{ms} \lt  t  \lt 4 \mathrm{ms},[/latex] diode is OFF and Capacitor has no path to discharge. Hence, at t=3 ms [latex] V_{\text {cap }}=3.3 \mathrm{V}[/latex]

question: Question 53 A CMOS inverter, designed to have a mid-point voltage [latex]V_I[/latex] equal to half of  [latex]V_{dd}[/latex], as shown in the figure, has the following parameters: [latex]V_{dd}[/latex]=3V [latex]\mu_n C_{ox}=100\mu A/V^2[/latex];  [latex]V_{tn}=0.7 V[/latex] for nMOS [latex]\mu_p C_{ox}=40\mu A/V^2[/latex];  [latex]|V_{tp}|=0.9 V[/latex] for pMOS The ratio of [latex]\left ( \frac{W}{L} \right )_n[/latex] to [latex]\left ( \frac{W}{L} \right )_p[/latex] is equal to ____(rounded off to 3 decimal places).
solution: [latex]I_{D n}=I_{D p} [/latex] and both will be in saturation [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{If }\quad V_{\mathrm{IN}}&=\frac{V_{D D}}{2}=1.5 \mathrm{V}=V_{\mathrm{GSN}}=V_{S G P} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{2}&\left(\mu_{n} C_{O x}\right)\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)_{n}\left[V_{\mathrm{GSN}}-V_{T N}\right]^{2} \\ =& \frac{1}{2}\left(\mu_{p} C_{Q x}\right)\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)_{p}\left[V_{G S P}+V_{T P}\right]^{2} \\ 100 \times 10^{-6}\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)_{n} &[1.5-0.7]^{2} \\ &=40 \times 10^{-6}\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)_{p}[1.5-0.9]^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)_{n}}{\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)_{p}}&=\frac{40}{100} \times \frac{(0.6)^{2}}{(0.8)^{2}}=0.225 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 In  the  circuit  shown,  the  threshold  voltages  of  the  pMOS  (|[latex]V_{tp}[/latex]|)  and  nMOS ([latex]V_{tn}[/latex])  transistors are both equal to 1 V. All the transistors have the same output resistance  [latex]r_{ds}[/latex] of 6 M[latex]\Omega[/latex]. The other parameters are listed below: [latex]\mu_n C_{ox}=60\mu A/V^2[/latex]; [latex]\left ( \frac{W}{L} \right )_{nMOS}=5[/latex] [latex]\mu_p C_{ox}=30\mu A/V^2[/latex]; [latex]\left ( \frac{W}{L} \right )_{pMOS}=10[/latex] [latex]\mu_n \; and \; \mu_p[/latex] are the carrier mobilities, and [latex]C_{ox}[/latex] is the oxide capacitance per unit area. Ignoring the  effect  of  channel  length  modulation  and  body  bias, the  gain  of  the  circuit  is____ (rounded off to 1 decimal place).
solution: [latex]M_{3}[/latex] and [latex]M_{4}[/latex] are identical PMOS transistor and they have equal current. Hence their [latex]V_{SG}[/latex] should be equal. [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{S G 3} &=V_{S G 4}=\frac{V_{D D}}{2}=2 V \\ I_{S D} &=\frac{\mu_{p} C_{o x}}{2}\left(\frac{W}{L}\right)_{p}\left(V_{S G}-\left|V_{T}\right|\right)^{2} \\ &=\frac{30}{2} \times 10(2-1)^{2}=150 \mu \mathrm{A} \end{aligned}[/latex] now, by using current mirror property all transistor should have equal current. [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{\mathrm{DSN}}&=I_{\mathrm{SDP}}=150 \mu \mathrm{A} \\ \text { For } M_{1} \quad g_{m 1}&=\sqrt{2 \mu_{n} C_{o x} \frac{W}{L} \times I_{D S}} \\ &=\sqrt{2 \mu_{n} C_{0 x}} \frac{W}{L} \times I_{D S}\\ & =\sqrt{2 \times 60 \times 5 \times 150}=300 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] M_{2}, M_{3} [/latex] and [latex] M_{4}[/latex] from active load for [latex]M_{1}[/latex]. This active load in equivalent to resistance [latex]r_{d s 2} i.e. 6 \mathrm{M} \Omega [/latex] [latex] M_{1}[/latex] is common source amplifier. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \frac{V_{\text {out }}}{V_{\text {in }}} &=A_{v}=-g_{m 1} \times\left(r_{\text {ds2 }} \| r_{\text {ds1 }}\right) \\ &=-300 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{C} \times 3 \mathrm{M} \Omega=-900 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 55 In the circuit shown, [latex]V_1=0 \; and \; V_2=V_{dd}[/latex].  The other relevant parameters are mentioned in the figure. Ignoring the effect of channel length modulation and the body effect, the value of [latex]I_{out}[/latex] is _____mA(rounded off to 1 decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{I_{2}}{I_{1}} &=\frac{(W / L)_{2}}{(W / L)_{1}}=\frac{3}{2} \\ I_{2} &=\frac{3}{2} \times I_{1}=1.5 \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] M_{3}[/latex] is OFF because [latex]V_{1}=0 \Rightarrow I_{3}=0 [/latex] [latex] M_{4}[/latex] is ON because [latex]V_{2}=V_{D D} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} I_{5} &=I_{4}=I_{2}=1.5 \mathrm{mA} \\ \frac{I_{6}}{I_{5}} &=\frac{(W / L)_{6}}{(W / L)_{5}}=\frac{40}{10}=4 \\ I_{6} &=4 I_{5}=4 \times 1.5=6 \mathrm{mA} \\ \therefore \quad I_{\text {out }} &=I_{6}=6 \mathrm{mA} \end{aligned}[/latex]
